19342534.review:
This is a game that makes me wish there as a third option to steam's "yes" and "no" if recommending the game. So I do recommend, it is a good purchase. But do so at your own risk.

I don't know anything at all about Hanafuda, but that is why I got the game. Probably still don't cause the tutorial talked about local rules and there are different "regions" you can play, but nothing seemed differet. And it's a lot of luck and memorization, 48 cards cateforized into the 12 months, 4 cards for each month, and all the combinations of them, with some of those combinations having their own rules of forming.

It's a really really pretty game. Even without the busty anime women on the stores front page. And she only appears in the tutorial mode, after you download the expansion pack and turn her on. So she can go completely unnoticed and you wouln't cause it's all pretty and traditional japanese stylish. The expansion that comes with the game also as extra cards designs and BGM that are equally as pretty. Art buget was not stingy.

But when I say luck I mean, Lady Luck is a dominatrix and you're her new bitch, kind of luck. One game I played I was winning 51-9 halfway through the game (there are 60 points total between the two players) and every round after that the com kept winning each round with the biggest point combination and eventually won the game with 2 points a head. I don't think I have ever been so mad at a game. I don't know if I suck or if the AI is suuuuuper hard. 

So it's a play at your own risk game. You may be good, you may bad. I'm probably bad cause I'm still new and I'm playing a against a hanafuda computer. I'd say get it cause to try and get yourself cultured.

18833399.review:
【花札】也成为花牌，STEAM上的花牌游戏不是很多，作为棋牌类的游戏，这个还算不错的。
AI 方面，感觉挺有挑战性的，模式也有地图攻略模式，地图模式上赢了AI会有当地日本风景美图，要收集全部的照片还是有点难度，越到后面AI越难，配牌越差，很多时候要看运，如果不好好考虑很容易被AI虐。
音乐，也算可以，但是曲子不多，重复听容易厌烦
其次就是界面了，对新手还是挺友好的，界面上能迅速查看役牌，哪些牌能够出都有提示，所以对于没玩过花牌的人还是非常容易上手。顺便这游戏还有一套新手教程，虽然没有中文比较可惜。

关于花牌，规则在百度百科什么都有教程可以学学，这游戏也只是当休闲，先手优势非常大，运气也占据了比较大的成分，但是也需要好好考虑下一步，如何遏制对手的役牌和打出自己适合的战术也是本卡牌游戏的乐趣所在，游戏中的こいこい（koikoi）是考验智商的最大地方也是感觉花牌中最具有乐趣和变量还有刺激性的地方，扩大优势，还是确保分数，能不能翻盘就是在这个十字路口中了。

总体来说 牌类游戏不太可能在游戏规则上创新，能做到中规中矩，界面合理，在休闲的时候来一发就够了。这款游戏基本上算合格了

18828903.review:
This review is for all my card playing and/or match 3 loving friends.  

Hanafuda, a traditional Japanese card, is well hard to describe.  It is like a combination of Go Fish, Old Maid, Bridge, Whist, Gin Rummy, Poker, Eucre, and Cribbage.  Instead of 13 cards in only 4 suits, there 4 cards per season or month with the added bonus of special higher point sets of 3 to 5 cards.  It is a bit confusing a first, I admit, but there is an in-game visual guide to the card hands.  Plus before beginning any card matches or tournment matches there is a very informative tutorial about how to play.  It also helps that your playing cards become highlighted along with the central "pot" cards to help find matches.  This card game is very challenging.

2.快速清爽的遊戲介面，就算初心者也能輕鬆上手。
3.機關算盡進退兩難，絕對讓你的koi koi賭性一本入魂。
4.有送殺必斯的免費DLC。

缺點

2.無連線功能。
3.教學功能冗長無用，自己上網維基比較快。


畫面風雅又黷武，遊戲尚禮又好鬥，規則喜新卻頑固。
玩後，讓我體驗出日本二元內心的極端矛盾。

18783224.review:
I had never heard of this card game.  It caught my attention in a Steam sale.  I was worried it would be super complicated, but the tutorial did a good job of quickly explaining the basics, and then right into Quick Play mode where after a couple games I felt like I had a pretty good idea what I was doing.  It's a fun game, a bit like poker, with the gambling aspect, and the different points for different series.  The hardest part is remembering what goes with what, and the game helps with that by highlighting valid moves, and with easy access to the rules.  Before I knew it I had already sunk a couple hours into my first session, was really enjoying it.  Haven't even touched the "Collection Mode" yet.

The presentation and interface is nice and polished.  It's a mouse and keyboard game, but was perfect to play from bed on the TV using the Steam controller.

I also purchased a physical deck on Amazon for $11, made by Nintendo.  It's an interesting story.  This is an ancient game, but I had no idea Nintendo actually got their start in 1889, selling these cards for 100 years prior to the NES...!  And still make and sell them to this day.

I also just got done streaming the movie Summer Wars on Vudu.  (First time using Vudu.  Can recommend.)  Highly, highly recommend the movie.  Check out a trailer.  Let's just say the card game Hanafuda makes several appearances and is significant to the plot.  But it's a great movie, reminiscent and of similar quality to Studio Ghibli films.  Apparently the game caught quite a few people's attention through that movie as well.

I was a little hesitant to purchase this due to the developers other uh... questionable... titles.  But this game is legit.

18768760.review:
珍しくこいこいを題材とした花札ゲーム。[strike]残念ながらマルチプレーはないが[/strike]、steam実績と各地の絵葉書収集モードがある。チュートリアルもあるし、ルール説明もしっかりしているので花札を知らない人でもすんなりゲームに入っていける。手札をマウスオーバーしただけで取れる場札が点滅するので、どの札がどの月かをきっちり覚える必要すらない（そのうち覚えると思うが）

ルール的にオプションで設定できるのは6ラウンド制か12ラウンド制のみで、役の有無や高さ、CPUの難易度選択は基本的に不可。他にはオプションで進行速度調整ができ、札を捨てた時の演出待ち時間が調節できる。ウィンドウモード時のサイズは1280x720で固定。

ゲーム紹介画面では巨乳の着物のお姉さんが目立つが、実際のゲームでは萌え要素はほとんどない。

コレクションモードは日本風景が描かれた絵葉書（全45枚) を集めるとあるが、実際には写真。閲覧モードでも絵葉書の場所の名前までは表示されないのが残念。地域は北海道、東北、関東、中部、近畿、中国、四国、九州、沖縄の9地域でそれぞれ5枚の絵葉書がある。
昔ながらの場所だけではなく、レインボーブリッジみたいな現代的な風景の場所も含まれる。
北海道地方をコンプしたが、内訳は松前城、小樽の北日本倉庫の看板、札幌時計台、富良野のラベンダー畑、流氷の中のおーろら号といったところ。

相手のAIについては月見酒と花見酒がそれぞれ1文役ということもあるのか、結構早めに盃の札を捨てたり（初手に取れないのに捨てたこともあった）、役が完成しても強気にこいこいするなど、月見酒と花見酒の評価が低く見積もられている気がした。おそらく残りターン数と手役の高低のみでこいこいするか否か決めており、手作りとか点差はあまり気にしていないと思われる。最終局で自分の負けを確定させる上がり(8文差で1文役を上がる)をしたり、こいこいを選択せず上がってれば勝ちの状況でなぜかこいこいを選択する場面も見られた。
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=545926977
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=575504300

あと時々ちゃんとシャッフルしたのかと言いたくなるような手札がくることもしばしば
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=574035611

実績は四光10回あがるのと五光10回あがるというのが別々の実績としてあるのがキツイと思われる。

いろいろ書いてきたが、操作でフラストレーションが溜まることもないので素直にこいこいをやりたいという人にはオススメです。

18754950.review: 作为一个任豚，对于花牌的感情是很特别的。高中看过一部叫做夏日大作战的剧场版动画，自此就爱上了花牌。后来又得知任天堂是做花牌起家的，于是乎花牌成为了我最喜欢的牌类运动。那么接下来就说说一说这款花牌游戏的问题吧。玩惯了任天堂做的花牌，BGM恰到好处，ai的可选择难度，各种特殊模式，自定人物等在这款游戏上一个都没有。秉承了这价开发商一贯的毫无诚意的作风。实话实说，手机上的在线对战的花牌都比这款游戏来的好玩。粗略的玩了两把，把把AI逆天。游戏节奏又拖泥带水（我已经把游戏速度调最快了），配上不痛不痒的BGM真的享受不到玩花牌的任何快感。赢得游戏获得的奖励也是跟手游一模一样，但是还不如手游的插画来的精致。花牌的皮肤还不能选择。总之还是这句话，这家开发商就是把红白机时代的AI带到一个看上去好一点的皮肤里，再拿出来卖。原本生日打算原价入，要不是今天打折真是被坑死。

18753869.review:
Edit: The recently released 2.0 update fixed almost all of the issues I had with the game.
Card animations aren't awkward anymore; there is online multiplayer; you can skip the displaying of the hands name by clicking (a huge improvement!). And even the banner isn't ridiculous anymore.
I have still an issue with the fixed rules and the AI, especially what seemed to be rigging for the few games I played (I have played hanafuda for over 20 years, and I have never experienced this much stacking of same month cards, let alone a case where there was 2 stacks of 3 cards at the start, with the computer opponent owning the last cards for both of them - let's call this incredibly bad luck, for the time being).

For archive purpose and show how much changed, the previous babbling is below :

[strike]This is a very, very basic hanafuda game.
For a start the interface and feel of it is very amateurish. Stills are nice, but once things start go get in motion... I confess before this game, I never would have thought you could fail at animating cards moving over a board. 
There is also the odd artistic choice on cards here and there, and the omnipresence of the English language, even if you set the game to Japanese.
There is of course no multiplayer, because who plays with real people?
Even against an automated opponent, the pacing of the game is pretty bad on fast setting, with scoring being handled by individual banners for each trick, one after the other - if you are familiar with the game, you know this can happen dozens of time in a big hand game.[/strike]
Then, and this one is a deal-breaker : there is the glaring absence of any (really, [u]any[/u]!) rule customization. They are all hard-set, and you better be glad with them.
The AI is also pretty stupid, not attempting to reverse a loss on the final month of a game, and stopping early.

[strike]You can get better, for free. And you can get infinitely better, for a small fee, on any phone or tablet.

Also, the boob-fishing on the game's Steam banner? Not awkward at all, and very classy![/strike]

15764541.review:
I bought this as an alternative to learning the game. I found the online rules very confusing and even with Online Flash Games i still struggled to understand the basic rules of the game!

I understood there were hands to collect, that each card had months pertaining to each flower set and that there was a points system that I didn't understand.

This game solved everything, sure its simple but its worth the £6 price tag, it functions as you would expect a real game so the replayability is just as replayable as the real life version, just with less cursing when you steal a set from someone! 

I used this as a learning tool, from the overlay that shows you each month and their card  flower sets and the Hands you could make with the sets that you could constantly check as you play so its less of a struggle! Not to mention as it was released the devs made sure as to fix up all the problems they've encountered meaning the game becomes stable, no doubt it was fixed very quickly as well! 

I doubt there'll be extra content because of the game itself can only go so far. 

Tl;Dr If you want to learn? Worth it. If you know the game? worth it.

15661061.review: A good way to learn the card game. The tutorial is well done, the UI is effective, and the musics are good, but there's only a few. The 'AI' is correct, but it's definitely not a real AI, it's rigged, and you'll often face the luckiest man in the world, but sometimes it'll be at your advantage, given the 'AI' is unable to stop at the right moment (If he stops, he wins the match, but he continues). 15622850.review:
NOTE: Played a lot offline so low playtime!

Having self taught this game to myself and a group of friends, I have a good perspective on this game to the majority of people only playing this card game for the first time. 

Positives:
1) Good Clean UI and very helpful card highlighting
- Memorising which card matches with which is abit hard for many people (November especially) and this game allows you to play without having to memorise, which is great for getting players right in.
2) AI is fierce
- A problem this game might have face would be an AI that just matches cards randomly but as far as I have seen the AI has been great so far. It capitalises on you being greedy and punishes you for it a lot.
3) Brilliant Tutorial
- I made slides to teach this game to my friends. This game has it all written down and the limits of the what moves you can make and identifying the Yaku immediately helps it with beginners a lot. I think anyone looking to learn Hanafuda should start with the game.

Negatives:
1) House Rules?
- The game at one stage said the game is played accross Japan with house rules and It would be GREAT if they had that here, especially with their collection mode which honestly needs a bit of more substance for it to have more replay value.
2) Multiplayer
- This game badly needs this for the game community to expand. I have actual Hanafuda cards so I can get by without it but having this multiplayer function would be brilliant for this game.
3) One Trick AI
- The AI is great and all but its play has little variance. Gets Yaku, 2 cards left? Stops. Gets 3 Brights? Chances are, stops. I have played with my friends and seen ridiculous draws like throwing down a Chrysanthenum card to only pick up a sake cup that just flipped open into double viewing combo (Moon, Sakura and Sake Cup). I don't see the AI having the balls to do that. I know making AI is hard but having some variance in AI, like one that plays more safely, another that plays aggressively will add so much depth into this game.

Looking at the collection mode, I feel that the game missed some chances to make it a Brilliant game because having all those individuals across Japan you can play against might be like some AI gauntlet with each with local house rules or differing AI. That would have been a strong feature that adds a lot of replayability but overall I love when traditional games like this get to see the light of day on Steam and gain a wider audience. Overall, I would reccomend this game to people who like traditional games that have a lot of luck involved but also a bit of skill.

15621278.review:
I admit I probably only got started playing this game because of anime film Summer Wars, and ever since watching it I've wanted to play the card game and now I can thanks to Steam!

It's an interesting, kind of addictive card game where you have to score points (or Yaku) using certain combinations of cards. I was kind of uncertain about how to play as the tutorial explains extreme basics of the game and not much else, but after playing a few quick games against the computer opponent you soon learn what's good and what's not.

The only way I can think to explain it to someone who has never played is it's a little like the  'snap' where you have to match playing cards, only instead of matching a 5 of a suit to another 5 of a suit you have to match flowers/trees of the month to other flowers/trees of the same month to collect cards (So 4 cards/flowers of 12 suits/months) and instead of matching your cards to your opponents, you match them to a selection of cards in the center of the play area. However, matching cards  doesn't mean you get points right away like you would if you were playing snap where you just have to get the most cards to win. Heck you could get points at the start of a round, only to lose them to the opponent at the end of the round. The points system is kind of like a tug of war, and it can go either way.

When you get a point-scoring combination of cards you get the option to say 'Koi Koi!' (Come on!) to your opponent. If you (or you opponent) call Koi Koi the music picks up the pace adding to the sense of... I want to say 'urgency' but I'm not sure that's the word I want... But it becomes a lot more fast-paced at least. Saying Koi Koi can mean more points to be won, but also more points to be lost, so it's  a bit of a gamble whether you carry on or not, but I find that's half the fun. Saying no to calling Koi Koi ends the round there.

It does take a bit of learning for the Yaku cominations, and maybe even for the months of the cards when choosing the dealer for the game, but it's quite fun when you learn it. I was terrified at first because I didn't know any of the months or what flowers or combinations would work, but at the top of a game screen you can click on the 'Cards' or 'Yaku' at any time and look at them. Not only that, but even if you don't look at those and you start a game, if you have any cards that match with the ones in the middle they're highlighted, and it's a helpful feature.

I've only played the Quick Game part of Koi Koi, I haven't tried the Collection mode, so I can't comment on that, but I like what I've played so far.

This is probably more for those who have an interest in Japan, but if you also have an interest in card games, it might be worth a look at. I'd probably give it an 8/10

15615514.review:
Koi-Koi is a fun and well made card game. You can think about it like a mini Mah-jong as each turn you try to grab cards to make a combo and get points (or rather steal points from your opponent). And like in Mah-jong, you start don't understanding what to do, for like 2~3 games, and then you start to see what combo you could do, and it gets really enjoyable, and addictive. The AI is quite good (a tad shy on the koi-koi but it's playing wisely, not like me).

The game is a faithful adaptation of the actual card game, the visuals are very nice, and the music is relaxing, even when it accelerate a bit after a koi-koi. So far,  the game only miss a local multiplayer [and a voiceover when you do a koi-koi like the objection ! in Phoenix Wright...]. 

I definitely recommend it for anyone wanting a simple and well made but addictive game !

15599947.review:
A very faithful rendition of Koi-Koi with a fairly smart A.I. opponent. The UI and presentation is about as beautiful and simplistic as the Hanafuda deck itself. You can jump in for a match instantly with Quick Play or try Collection Mode, which is a sort of "campaign" like mode where you choose a region of Japan and face an opponent in a game of Koi-Koi. The main focus of this mode is to collect postcards that depict beautiful photographs taken in the region you chose previously.

Overall, it's simply Koi-Koi, and that's all you really need a game like this to be. It's presented in a lovely way and there's even a tutorial for new players. The game goes as far as highlighting possible matches for yakus, and even a complete list of both the cards and yakus for you to look over at a glance.

If you are new to Koi-Koi and are interested in learning to play it, or a long time fan of the age old playing card game, it's certainly worth picking up!
